text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The candidate answer explicitly addresses the concept of actual occupation and notice in relation to the lender's priority. It asks, \"Were you living at the property when they conducted their valuation?\" and later states, \"If you were in actual occupation, *Williams & Glyn's Bank v Boland* [1981] establishes that your occupation gives constructive notice to anyone dealing with the property.\" It also advises the user to gather evidence of occupation (utility bills, photos, etc.). This directly satisfies the requirement of advising that actual occupation means physical presence or clear signs of habitation apparent to a reasonable lender.", "criterion_id": "52652878-e3f0-4e46-ac6b-dde189cd58b5"}
